conclusion: Determine the area of the square coil exposed to the magnetic field.
The image shows a square coil with a side length of \( a \). Half of it is in a uniform magnetic field, perpendicular to the field.
The magnetic induction intensity increases uniformly from \( B \) to \( 2B \) over a time interval \( \Delta t \).
The square coil has \( n \) turns and each side has a length of \( a \).
Only half of the coil is in the magnetic field, so the exposed area is \( \frac{1}{2}a^2 \).
The magnetic induction intensity increases from \( B \) to \( 2B \) over \( \Delta t \).
The induced EMF \( \mathcal{E} \) in the coil is given by the formula \( \mathcal{E} = n \cdot \frac{\Delta \Phi}{\Delta t} \).
The change in magnetic flux \( \Delta \Phi \) is \( \frac{1}{2}a^2 \cdot B \).
Substitute \( \Delta \Phi \) into the formula for induced EMF: \( \mathcal{E} = n \cdot \frac{a^2 \cdot B}{2 \Delta t} \).
The problem states the EMF induced in the coil is \( n \cdot \frac{a^2 \cdot B}{2 \Delta t} \).
